Sure. Sure. Okay. That makes sense. Jeff, I know you talked a bit about R&D up 14% year-over-year, and you are trying to stimulate new products. I mean, how do you see that growth in R&D? I mean, pretty much since you have taken the job, you have had a nice focus on R&D, but up 14% is a pretty good number. When you look for 2011, 2012, kind of the out-years, is there some sort of sweet spot that you hit that you don't need to kind of grow it any more, where you have your platforms funded...?

Definitely, Scott. I kind of peg it at kind of between 5 and 6% of the – you know, of our industrial revenue, and, you know, we're going to have about 30% more products this year than in the past, and I think you see that with our market share in Healthcare, and, you know, as you know this is what sets up the service revenue and all of the things that come with it.
So, you know, I always think that's a sweet spot that gives us a competitiveness position against all of our key – you know, key competitors.
Sure. So basically growing with revenues from here, or growing ahead of revenues?
I would say growing more or less with revenues from here.

Okay. And just to narrow it down a little bit, you know, clearly, you'll have a little bit more R&D in the – in the aviation side. I mean, does that mean you can take a little bit from an area that does haven't quite the growth potential?

You know, what I would say is we're going to look across the portfolio. I spike out aviation because I think they are in a particular cycle, and there might be opportunities to reallocate inside – inside the company. But we also still see good potential for Healthcare and Energy and some of our other platforms as well.

I think it's the most valuable growth we can do. If we can invest in technology to improve our organic growth, and we're committed to it, every single one of our strategic plans that we went through this year, Scott, the number one thing is what is the R&D deck to continue to improve our competitive position?
Sure.
The teams are committed to it and I think it's a better place for the company to be at these levels of R&D spending.

Sure. Sure, agreed. Just to, again, narrow in on it, one of the potential side effects you could argue on health imagination is it maybe not as much of a focus on the arms race, and, you know, the next generation of...
I think that's right.
Does that mean...?
But when I look at health imagination, though, the share we're gaining on the lower end in places like China and India is substantial.
But that doesn't require quite as much...
Exactly.
...R&D spend, right?
Yeah.

Okay. And lastly, Keith, just to clarify, the CFOA has been fantastic, and working capital has come out pretty aggressively. Are we pretty close to being done with what you can do in working capital now that, you know, presumably your growth rates are bottoming out and you will start to build backlog again?

I don't think so. We basically, as I said, we went through the strategic plan this summer. We're trying to get a goal. We have benchmarks for every one of our businesses, and the goal that we would have is probably about half a turn of working capital improvement each year to continue to offset the growth that we have in the businesses or any pressure from progress collections. And two years ago we stated that as our goal, and we have been able to deliver that through the first half of all of 2009, and the first half of 2010.

We have an operating council, we meet every month, the teams are focused on improving their processes, our working capital turnover went up in the second quarter, again, a couple of tenths in receivables and inventory and accounts payable and you know, there's more to do here in terms of using lean, and being more efficient and sharing practices across the company where we have better performance.

You know, Scott, when you look at our long term incentive plan, one of the big drivers is cumulative cash flow from operating activities, so all of the leadership team is incented to drive working capital improvement and strong CFOA and I think this is what you see in the execution.
Okay. Sounds great. Thanks, guys.
Thanks, Scott.
Your next question comes from the line of Jason Feldman from UBS.
Good morning.
Good morning, Jason.

So you've talked a couple of times now about expecting 25 billion of cash at the parent level by the end of the year. I guess I'm just kind of wondering how much you really need to keep there? I mean in finance you have got better capital ratios, and leverage ratios than -- for some time, if ever. How much of a backstop do you still really need at the parent level? Or how much of that can you deploy?

You know, we haven't really decided yet on this one. You know, I would say clearly we're going to have more cash in the future than we had pre-crisis, but with $25 billion we're going to have substantial flexibility to do the things we want to do to grow the company. I don't know, Keith, would you add to that?

Yeah, sure, I think we're actually – priority number one was to make the company safe and secure. We've crossed that threshold. I think you mentioned at GE Capital, we've got enough capital. We've got a lot of cash. We've got enough cash to handle any liquidity issues there. We're looking from an enterprise risk perspective at how much capital do you need at the parent for unforeseen events, for systemic risks and it is going to be some amount obviously more than we used to hold. We used to hold $2 billion at the parent and it's going to be more than that but we haven't given a specific number.

But even above whatever that threshold is, we're going to have substantial cash. We're going to be able to redeploy all the NBCU cash and a lot of our free cash flow from the business operations into capital activities that will improve the future value, as Jeff said.

Okay. And last question is – you mentioned, you know, not just today but in the past that you have far fewer competitors in the finance business than pre-crisis. At least one large bank, I think another as well mentioned sharply higher originations in the small business lending area. Have you seen an uptick in competitions as the banks have begun to recover or any change in the competitive environment?

You know, I would say we really haven't in the spaces we're in. I think you have got to remember where GE Capital is. We're like deep in things like private label credit cards, retail – you know, mid-market lending, aircraft leasing, you know, in the places where we are, sure we're going to have competitors, but I think we have pretty unique scale niches, and that's – it's – we feel good about our dynamics.
Okay. Thank you.
Good.
Noelia, why don't we take one more question. We have been going for a while here.
Thank you. Your final question comes from the line of John Inch from Merrill Lynch.
Thank you. Good morning, everyone.
Hey, John.
Good morning, John.

Good morning, guys. So the implication, I think Jeff, you made the statement of the 25 billion is still expected by year end in cash. Does that imply that NBC is still on track to close by year end, and I'm assuming there is some sort of dovetailing with EU approval?

John, I hate to predict exactly when it is going to close, just because we don't control it, but we don't see – we don't see anything today that changes what we have said in the past, and so I – we put that in as a marker, but again, remember, we don't control it, and so I want to respect the process.
Sure. I understand.

The 25 billion assumes it closes by year end, but what if it pushes out a little bit? We're still going to get that capital, we do believe that deal is going to close, but there is a timing question. Right now our teams are working very constructively with both the DOJ and SEC. We filed all the information. We're in active dialogue, and the formal clocks end sometime in November, so we're going to work like crazy to get that closed by year end, but that's tied to that assumption, obviously.
And the delta is like what, about an 8 billion...?
$8 billion, yeah.
And Keith, the cash impact of Lake, is it materially different than what we see in terms of the charge-offs per quarter? Like was it different than the $0.02 and kind of what's the trend there?

Yeah, there was no cash impact of yet of Lake. But ultimately the amounts we pay above the 2.2 billion will be cash paid to Shinsei for the claims. It's going to be dollar for dollar, the reserve amounts will be cash in Japan, and these are without any tax affects so there's dollar for dollar on the reserve increases.

Okay. That makes sense. Last question, more of a housekeeping, on the balance sheet I think the liabilities associated with businesses held for sale seemed to go up a lot sequentially, but it didn't look like the assets of the businesses held for sale were up that much. Is there something meaningful there? I think it was about $4 billion and change.
Sure. We completed the NBCU debt offering. If you remember in the quarter we borrowed...
Yes.
We have $6 billion of term financing that we needed to do before we closed the deal. We did $4 billion of that...
Okay.
...here in the second quarter. A very successful offering, so that's what that is.
Okay, great. Thanks, guys.
Great. Thanks, everyone for your time and questions today.
Just to close out, the replay of today's webcast will be available this afternoon, and I have a few housekeeping items to close out here.

First we'll be distributing our quarterly supplemental data schedule for GE Capital later today. In the past we have issued this in conjunction with our 10-Q, so we wanted to get the data in your hands sooner.
Second we have our analyst meeting at the Farnborough Air Show next week on July 20. And please visit our website for details there.

Third, we'll be scheduling a GE Capital webcast for later this year. We've had several of our leaders, including Mike Neal out at sell-side conferences, so we haven't done our webcast, but we'll still be doing one later this year, so we'll send out details once that is finalized.
Finally, our third quarter 2010 earnings webcast will take place on Friday, October 15, and as always Joanne and I are here to take questions and go through anything you have. Thanks, everyone.
Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes your conference. Thank you for your participation today. You may now disconnect.
